question.text: In the Hoffmann bromamide degradation reaction, the number of moles of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaOH</mi></math> and <math><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> used per mole of amine produced are:

options.text: Two moles of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaOH</mi></math> and two moles of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>

Four moles of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaOH</mi></math> and one mole of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>

One mole of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaOH</mi></math> and one mole of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>

Four moles of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaOH</mi></math> and two moles of <math><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>
